citation.article-title: Lactobacillus equi sp. nov., a predominant intestinal Lactobacillus species of the horse isolated from faeces of healthy horses.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lactobacillus equi sp. nov.
Lactobacillus equi (e'qui. L. n. equus horse; L. gen. n. equi of the horse)
Colonies on MRS agar are white, smooth, convex and approximately 2 mm in diameter.
Cells occur singly and in pairs and are 0.7 (0.6-0.8)x2.7 (1.3-3.5) μm in size.
Facultatively anaerobic, catalase-negative and obligately homofermentative.
Most strains grow at 45 °C, but not at 15 °C.
D- and L-lactic acid are produced from glucose.
Acid is produced from galactose, glucose, fructose, mannitol, maltose, lactose, melibiose, sucrose and raffinose.

Acid is not produced from glycerol, erythritol, D-arabinose, L-xylose, adonitol, b-methyl-D- xyloside, sorbose, dulcitol, inositol, α-methyl-dmannoside, α-methyl-D-glucoside, amygdalin, cellobiose, trehalose, melezitose, starch, glycogen, xylitol, gentiobiose, D-lyxose, D-tagatose, D-fucose, L-fucose, D-arabitol, L-arabitol, gluconate, 2-ketogluconate and 5-ketogluconate.
Most strains produce no acid from larabinose, D-xylose, arbutin, salicin and inulin.
Reactions of aesculin hydrolysis and acid production from rhamnose, sorbitol, N-acetylglucosamine, ribose, mannose and D-turanose are variable.
The DNA G+­C content of the type strain is 38% (as determined by HPLC).
The type strain is strain YIT 0455T (=ATCC BAA-261T=JCM 10991T)
